intro: Corydalis gorodkovii var. coerulea, commonly known as the blue corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that range in color from pale blue to violet. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine habitats, preferring well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a hairy texture, while its stems are slender and branching. This variant is prized for its ornamental value and is occasionally cultivated in gardens for its aesthetic appeal.
